metadata.case_name: Burmah Shell Oil Storage Distributing Company of India Ltd. v. Belgaum Borough Municipality

facts.text: The Company deals in petrol and other petroleum products manufactured in refineries outside octroi limits of Belgaum Municipality and brings them inside for use or consumption by itself or for sale to dealers, licensees, Government, local bodies and private concerns.
Company has Divisional Office and Depot in Belgaum; petition filed by Divisional Manager.

Goods brought by Company divided into four categories: (1) Goods consumed by the Company; (2) Goods sold by Company through dealers or itself and consumed within octroi limits by others; (3) Goods sold inside limits but consumed outside; (4) Goods sent from Depot inside to extra-municipal points.
Period concerned: October 22, 1955 to October 22, 1958; octroi duty levied on all goods irrespective of categories: Rs. 1,40,544.51.
Company claimed not liable for categories 2,3,4; High Court rejected claim but Municipality agreed to refund category 4 per rules.
Company commenced proceedings under Article 226 for writ to prohibit Municipality from levying octroi on products brought for sale; petition dismissed by Mysore High Court on May 31, 1960.

Belgaum Municipality governed by Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act, 1925; power to levy octroi under section 73(iv): on animals or goods brought within octroi limits for consumption, use or sale therein (sale added by Bombay Act 35 of 1954 effective May 5, 1954).
Procedure for imposing tax: sections 75,76; rules under section 58(j); by-laws under section 61(n).
Octroi Rules and By-laws framed in 1925 continued; rule 4(1) not reframed post-1954 amendment.
Company paid octroi on all products; post-amendment correspondence claimed rules/by-laws needed reframing per sections 75-77, 58(j), 60; Municipality agreed to refund on re-export per rules.
Dispute narrowed to categories 2 and 3; Company admits liability on category 1; Municipality refunds category 4 on proof.

legal_issues.text: Whether octroi under Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act, 1925 s.73(iv) prior to 1954 amendment leviable on goods brought into octroi limits for sale therein (not consumed/used by importer), or only for consumption/use by importer.
Whether post-1954 amendment adding 'sale', procedure under ss.75,76,58(j),60 required to levy octroi on goods brought for sale, as it amounts to new tax.

petitioner_arguments.text: Words 'consumption or use' contrast with 'sale'; prior to amendment, octroi only if consumed/used by person bringing goods, not if sold to others for their consumption/use.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Entry 49 List II GOI Act 1935; Entry 52 State List Constitution; Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act s.73(iv) pre-1954

petitioner_arguments.text: Post-amendment, 'sale' introduces new tax requiring fresh procedure under ss.75,76,58(j),60 as rules/by-laws not reframed.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act ss.75,76,58(j),60,77; Burmah Shell Oil Storage v. Manmad Municipality AIR 1958 Bom 43

respondent_arguments.text: Prepared to grant refund on goods actually sent outside octroi limits on proof thereof, per rules.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Octroi Rules and By-laws; Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act s.61(n)

court_reasoning.text: Octroi historically on goods brought into local area for consumption, use or sale therein; pre-1954, sale implicit if goods sold inside for consumption/use by buyers therein, not mere transit.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'Consumption' has wider meaning including distribution to consumers; 'use' covers goods not used up; goods brought for sale to ultimate consumer inside area taxable even if consumed outside.

court_reasoning.text: 1954 amendment did not alter nature/incidence/rate of tax; no new tax, thus no need for fresh procedure under ss.75-77 etc.; rules continued valid.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Amplification aligned with constitutional description but octroi concept always included sale for consumption/use inside.

court_reasoning.text: Distinction from terminal tax; octroi requires intent for consumption/use/sale therein, with refunds/exemptions for re-export.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Taxable event is entry for repose in area leading to ultimate use/consumption by someone therein.

holdings.text: Company liable to pay octroi on goods brought into area (a) for consumption by itself or sold to consumers direct, (b) for sale to dealers who sell to consumers within area, irrespective of where consumers use them.
No liability on re-exported goods, but refund per rules required.
1954 amendment did not require fresh imposition procedure; tax remained same.

precedents_cited.case_name: Burmah Shell Oil Storage and Dist. Co. v. Manmad Municipality
precedents_cited.relevance: Reliance by petitioner that new tax post-amendment needs procedure

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay v. United Motors India Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Explanation of 'consumption' in Art.286(1): reference to distribution to consumers generally, not just importer

precedents_cited.case_name: Anwarkhan Mahboob Co. v. State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Wider meaning of 'consumption' including any user ordinarily so called, intermediate/final acts

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act, 1925
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to levy octroi on goods brought for consumption/use/sale therein; procedure for imposition; rules/by-laws for refunds

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal; writ jurisdiction; explanation of consumption

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1935
statutes_cited.relevance: Cesses/taxes on entry of goods into local area for consumption/use/sale

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Act 35 of 1954
statutes_cited.relevance: Substituted 'use or sale' for 'or use' effective May 5, 1954

outcome.summary: Appeal against Mysore High Court dismissal of writ petition fails; Company liable for octroi on categories 2 and 3; refunds for category 4 per rules.
outcome.relief_granted: None; Municipality to refund category 4 on proof per rules

key_quotes.text: 'The expression for the purpose of consumption in that State must... be understood as having reference not merely to the individual importer or purchaser but as contemplating distribution eventually to consumers in general within the State.'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines broad scope of 'consumption' including by others

key_quotes.text: The act of consumption... consists in the act of taking such advantage of the commodities... as constitutes the utilization thereof.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Expands 'consumption' to any ordinary user, final or intermediate

key_quotes.text: In this context, the word consumption... must receive a larger meaning than merely the act of consuming in the generally understood sense.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interprets octroi liability beyond importer's personal use
